habitat_description:
This species only occurs in the Colorado and Concho river drainages, in Texas (Ernst and Ernst 2003; Scott et al. 1989; Smith et al. 1996; Tennant 1998; Werler and Dixon 2000). The current range consists of 396 stream kilometers compared to 450 kilometers in previous times; though reduced it now includes lakes Spence, Moonen, and Ivie (Scott et al. 1989; Smith et al. 1996; Tennant 1998).

The habitat is primarily characterized by creeks, and low to high gradient rivers, and shallow water pools. Riparian habitats include bare rocks, talus, and scree. Burrowing takes place using or in soil, ground litter, and fallen logs (Natureserve.org). This species is associated with fast flowing rocky streams where can be readily observed basking on rocks near the water’s edge. Similarly, shorelines of impoundments, ponds, and lakes (Werler and Dixon 2000). Whithing et al. (1997) described with more detail the strong association of this species with rocky, low-gradient, and silty shorelines. Cover is provided by the dense vegetation of riparian zones, but also rocks along the shoreline play an important role (Conant 1975; Ernst and Ernst 2004; Gibbons and Dorcas 2004; Scott et al. 1989; Tennant 1984). Hibernation locations include rock piles and crayfish burrows (Werler and Dixon 2000).

GP - 	This species is found in areas suitable for juveniles; these are associated with flat rocks that provide basking and hiding opportunities, cracks and gaps that aid in foraging.
